channel.title: Introduction on RTFM DevOps
channel.description: Recent content in Introduction on RTFM DevOps

item.description: kubectl cheatsheet Connection details To look at the connection details, we can either see the content of the ~/.kube/config file (on Linux) or run the following command: $ kubectl config view Cluster info kubectl cluster-info When not using the kubectl proxy, we need to authenticate to the API server when sending API requests. We can authenticate by providing a Bearer Token when issuing a curl, or by providing a set of keys and certificates.

Ingress "An Ingress is a collection of rules that allow inbound connections to reach the cluster Services." To allow the inbound connection to reach the cluster Services, Ingress configures a Layer 7 HTTP/HTTPS load balancer for Services and provides the following: TLS (Transport Layer Security) Name-based virtual hosting Fanout routing Loadbalancing Custom rules. With Ingress, users do not connect directly to a Service. Users reach the Ingress endpoint, and, from there, the request is forwarded to the desired Service.

item.title: (Hu)go Template Primer
item.description: Hugo uses the excellent Go html/template library for its template engine. It is an extremely lightweight engine that provides a very small amount of logic. In our experience that it is just the right amount of logic to be able to create a good static website.

Volume Types A directory which is mounted inside a Pod is backed by the underlying Volume Type. A Volume Type decides the properties of the directory, like size, content, default access modes, etc. Some examples of Volume Types are: emptyDir An empty Volume is created for the Pod as soon as it is scheduled on the worker node. The Volume’s life is tightly coupled with the Pod. If the Pod is terminated, the content of emptyDir is deleted forever.
